pull.title: test: Fix intermittent issue in p2p_addr_relay.py

events.body: Can be reviewed with `--color-moved=dimmed-zebra` to reduce the review burden by 3 lines :sweat_smile:

Thanks for the fix and Concept ACK. See https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/21707#discussion_r620085210 - there is another occurrence in `blocksonly_mode_tests`  of `p2p_addr_relay.py` that should be changed as well - by calling the `send_addr_msg()` helper as suggested by John or directly there.
Concept ACK, hit this issue today.

ACK fa5211d9e0, thanks for this fix. agree with mzumsande's  https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/21785#issuecomment-827538135, ready to reACK if you incorporate. also left some wording suggestions to consider.

events.message: test: Fix intermittent issue in p2p_addr_relay.py

events.body: ACK faa51ef4d33034f8c14cfd18f1c01c90883a1bb4. Looks good. Thanks Marco.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -539,8 +539,16 @@ def send_and_ping(self, message, timeout=60):
         self.send_message(message)
         self.sync_with_ping(timeout=timeout)
 
-    # Sync up with the node
+    def sync_send_with_ping(self, timeout=60):
+        """Ensure any to-be-received message on this connection is processed by SendMessages"""
+        # Calling sync_with_ping twice requires that the node calls
+        # `ProcessMessage` twice, and thus ensures `SendMessages` must have
+        # been called at least once
+        self.sync_with_ping()
+        self.sync_with_ping()
+
     def sync_with_ping(self, timeout=60):
+        """Ensure any sent message on this connection is processed by ProcessMessages"""
comments.body:
thanks for adding description here & in `sync_send_with_ping`, but imo it could be clearer. offering a suggestion incase you agree this captures the mechanism better:

"Ensure the recipient node has run ProcessMessages for all previously sent p2p messages"

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -539,8 +539,16 @@ def send_and_ping(self, message, timeout=60):
         self.send_message(message)
         self.sync_with_ping(timeout=timeout)
 
-    # Sync up with the node
+    def sync_send_with_ping(self, timeout=60):
+        """Ensure any to-be-received message on this connection is processed by SendMessages"""
comments.body:
to consider:

"Ensure the recipient node has run ProcessMessages and SendMessages for all previously sent p2p messages"

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -539,8 +539,16 @@ def send_and_ping(self, message, timeout=60):
         self.send_message(message)
         self.sync_with_ping(timeout=timeout)
 
-    # Sync up with the node
+    def sync_send_with_ping(self, timeout=60):
+        """Ensure any to-be-received message on this connection is processed by SendMessages"""
+        # Calling sync_with_ping twice requires that the node calls
+        # `ProcessMessage` twice, and thus ensures `SendMessages` must have
+        # been called at least once
+        self.sync_with_ping()
+        self.sync_with_ping()
+
     def sync_with_ping(self, timeout=60):
+        """Ensure any sent message on this connection is processed by ProcessMessages"""
comments.body: Isn't ''**any** message" too strong (instead of "at least one message"), especially here but also above?  `ProcessMessages`, `ProcessMessage` and `SendMessages`  can all return early. With `SendMessages`, it goes together with a disconnect, but for `ProcessMessage(s)` there are many other ways, so that in case of multiple messages not all might have been processed in this iteration of the loop.

         self.sync_with_ping(timeout=timeout)

+        """Ensure any to-be-received message on this connection is processed by SendMessages"""
+        # Calling sync_with_ping twice requires that the node calls
+        # `ProcessMessage` twice, and thus ensures `SendMessages` must have
+        # been called at least once
+        self.sync_with_ping()
+        self.sync_with_ping()
+
     def sync_with_ping(self, timeout=60):
+        """Ensure any sent message on this connection is processed by ProcessMessages"""
comments.body: you make a good point, I was making an assumption about test setup that isn't necessarily true.
